description: A Roman road-side settlement running alongside Ermine street, twelve timber and masonry buildings were recorded. At the eastern end, one of the masonry buildings with a mid-2nd CE construction date was interpreted as a shrine. Many of the buildings were 'destroyed' in the mid 4th CE.
bibliography: Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Water Newton, Kate’s Cabin Farm (Cambridgeshire).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.
Perrin. “Roman Pottery from Excavations at and near to the Roman Small Town of Durobrivae, Water Newton, Cambridgeshire, 1956-58.” Journal of Roman Pottery Studies 8 (1999).
“Roman Britain in 1957: I. Sites Explored: II. Inscriptions.” The Journal of Roman Studies 48 (1958).
Wright. “Roman Britain in 1958: I. Sites Explored: II. Inscriptions.” The Journal of Roman Studies 49 (1959).
